title: 109_hr5612
content: The Act titled "Chattahoochee National Forest Act of 2006" includes a section establishing the Mountaintown National Scenic Area within the Chattahoochee National Forest in Georgia. The Mountaintown National Scenic Area is established in the Chattahoochee National Forest in Georgia, covering approximately 13,382 acres. The Secretary of Agriculture will provide a final map and boundary description for the scenic area, which will be available for public inspection. The Mountaintown National Scenic Area in Georgia, covering 13,382 acres, will have a boundary description available for public inspection. The Secretary will manage the area for protection of scenic and natural qualities, wildlife habitat, old-growth characteristics, and recreation opportunities. The Mountaintown National Scenic Area in Georgia, covering 13,382 acres, will be managed to protect scenic and natural qualities, wildlife habitat, old-growth characteristics, and recreation opportunities. A management plan must be developed within three years, and the management purposes specified in the plan take precedence over general laws and regulations. No new roads will be constructed after the enactment of this Act. After the enactment of this Act, no new roads shall be constructed within the Mountaintown National Scenic Area in Georgia. Timber harvest is prohibited except for fire, insect, and disease control, public safety, and trail access. Motorized travel is not allowed, but the Secretary may authorize exceptions. Firewood can be harvested for personal use along perimeter roads under specified conditions. Vegetation manipulation practices are allowed for wildlife maintenance and visual quality in the scenic area. Motorized travel is generally prohibited, but exceptions may be made for administrative use and wildlife management projects. Wildfires will be suppressed to align with management purposes. Insect and disease outbreaks may be controlled to maintain scenic quality. Water quality in the area will be maintained or enhanced. Mining activities are restricted, except for valid existing rights. Insects and disease outbreaks in the scenic area may be controlled to maintain scenic quality and prevent tree mortality. Water quality will be maintained or enhanced. Federally owned lands in the area are withdrawn from mining activities, except for valid existing rights. Designation of additional national forest system land as wilderness in Georgia. Designation of approximately 8,448 acres of land in Georgia as wilderness, adding to existing wilderness areas in Chattahoochee National Forest. Includes additions to Southern Nantahala, Blood Mountain, Brasstown, Ellicott Rock, and Cohutta Wilderness areas. Designation of approximately 8,448 acres of land in Georgia as wilderness, adding to existing wilderness areas in Chattahoochee National Forest. Includes additions to Duck Branch, Wilson Cove, Ellicott Rock Addition, Foster Branch, Ken Mountain, Helton Creek, and Tripp Branch wilderness areas. Secretary to submit final maps and boundary descriptions to Congress. The Congress finalizes maps and boundary descriptions for designated wilderness lands, with the Secretary able to make corrections. The lands will be administered in accordance with the Wilderness Act, with the effective date deemed to be the enactment of this Act. The Federal land designated as wilderness by this section is withdrawn from all forms of entry, appropriation, or disposal under public land laws, mining laws, and laws pertaining to mineral and geothermal leasing or mineral materials.
